column1: Will the Council of the European Union make an Article 7.1 determination against Hungary before 31 December 2020?
column6: ['Non-US Politics']

"...on Monday when Hungary and Poland blocked the stimulus plan and the broader budget, cracking open one of the bloc’s most persistent, existential divisions over what a European Union democracy looks like ... at the insistence of the European Parliament, which must approve spending, the budget bill passed earlier this month included language making the funds contingent on rule of law standards that the E.U. considers fundamental to its values. The item was clearly aimed at the Hungarian and Polish governments, which have defiantly chipped away at independent judiciaries among other democratic norms." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/16/world/europe/eu-stimulus-poland-hungary.html

EU currently has other concerns with Turkey situation making this more complex. A fight with Hungary isn't being widely mentioned currently

Germany's presidency ends on 31 December 2020, but articles below make it seem as though Hungary will also be subject to a 7.1 before its end.

Hungary’s Orban demands resignation of EU’s rule-of-law chief. Prime minister hits back at top Brussels official who branded country a ‘sick democracy’. The commission said that Ms von der Leyen worked closely with Ms Jourova on the rule-of-law agenda and had “full trust” in her. “Our concerns about the rule-of-law situation in Hungary are well known,” the EU executive added.
Going up to 10% on recent developments. Besides the article @juancambeiro links to, these other two came out recently:

This [1] is an excellent read on how Viktor Orban has escaped facing any serious consequences from the EU for his undermining of Hungary's rule of law and democratic institutions. Here's a part that's especially relevant to this question: "Hungary presents a puzzle for the EU, as it prepares to roll out its first rule of law report assessing the bloc’s 27 member countries on September 30 ... few expect it [the EU] to stop Orbán’s abuse of the rule of law ... while it [the EU] formally triggered Article 7 proceedings against Warsaw in 2017, it did not do so for Budapest ... It was only after the European Parliament acted in 2018 and formally triggered Article 7 that proceedings were started against Hungary ... There is a sense in the Council — even among some governments that dislike Orbán's policies — that Article 7 should be avoided. The worry is that isolating a member country could put further pressure on the bloc even as it is still recovering from the United Kingdom’s decision to leave" [2].

our former failed defense minister and now eu commission president wants to force other eu countries to adopt germanys open border policy after some asylumseekers burned down their camps in greece because they demanded more orban will not agree to that so maybe they then want to punish him symbolically https://de.nachrichten.yahoo.com/leyen-fordert-brandkatastrophe-moria-gemeinsames-140207497.html

Great read: "Viktor Orban’s emergency rule by decree has ended for now, but the return to illiberal politics as usual incites fear and stifles dissent." https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/07/17/hungary-democracy-still-under-threat-orban-state-public-health-emergency-decree/

A demand by the European Parliament’s Civil Liberties Committee, advanced by Dutch Green MEP Judith Sargentini to invoke Article 7 against Hungary for ‘weakening of the Constitutional Court and the judiciary, corruption, restrictions on freedom of expression, assembly and intimidation of the media, non-governmental organizations and research institutions.’ Article 7(1), which is a determination rather than an action, would see a formal warning given to the country accused of violating fundamental rights. There does appear to be reticence by the EU to punish Orban due to political considerations. Fidesz is the political party of the Hungarian President Orban and belongs to the centre right European People’s Party (EPP) grouping within the European Parliament that includes Merkel and Veradkar. They do not want to isolate Orban due to his ability to supply votes and therefore maintaining the group’s influence. This was in April 2018. In September 2018, the Eu Parliament voted to issue Article 7 (1) to Hungary, which opens the door to sanctions, but Article 7 can only be enacted if all the EU members agree, which is problematical as Poland is in a similar position to Hungary and they will support each other. The EU is currently distracted by the Coronavirus pandemic, Brexit and the resultant budgetary woes. Hungary has also become the largest recipient of EU aid to combat the outcomes of the pandemic even though the country suffered less than others within the EU Community. Therefore, the chances of Hungary being subjected to Article 7 would appear to be slim. https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2020/04/europe-hungary-viktor-orban-coronavirus-covid19-democracy/609313/
Investigation yes but determination no.
Ship has sailed now decree revoked and European unity (even with Orban) the priority at moment.
Joining others in pegging my forecast for reasons they have stated.

Adjusting down as rule by decree is ending; while Orban may keep the same broad authority, it is less likely that he would come into blatant conflict with the EU unless he does something very egregious
Revising down as Orban looks likely to end his rule by decree soon which will drop the issue from the agenda.

With Orban's consent, Hungary's parliament has voted to end Orban's emergency rule-by-decree powers [1,2]. However, this is not a complete rollback of the emergency powers that have empowered Orban — "An analysis by Karoly Eotvos Institute, a democracy watchdog in Budapest, concluded that the legislation approved on Tuesday had no intention of restoring Hungary’s pre-coronavirus legal order, 'but rather creates a legal basis for the use of newer extraordinary and unlimited government powers.'" [2]

Germany will take over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union on 01 July 2020 and will likely position themselves as the "Guardians of the Treaties" ahead of other new issues raised by trouble-making nations in the EU. In the conclusion, there is likely tough talk from October on (since Germany is seeing the beginning of their general election rallies) but no real confrontation. However, Hungary will keep testing the core-European nations' patience on every occasion. Clashes towards year end 2020 are becoming more likely, and so is the risk of a escalation for real.

They would have to vote in entirely new procedures and that would take time. Already went down the 7.1 road with Poland and Hungary and got nowhere. https://verfassungsblog.de/the-european-parliament-sidelined/ https://bridgenetwork.eu/2020/01/22/the-rule-of-law-in-the-eu-the-january-2020-edition/
Unlikely

It's never been used, and it's been a couple of years since proceedings were launched so difficult to say how long they would take. The current social distancing means it would be very hard to conduct proceedings, and EU focus likely to be on COVID response anyway. Legally it's a tricky issue - the measures don't 'literally' violate constitutional rights as parliament has ability to end state of emergency (in theory). Also conceivable that other countries could employ similar emergency measures justified by COVID, so where do you draw the line? There is talk that the rule by decree could end soon which would lower pressure to use Article 7.
It might not happen that soon.
Can’t see the EU taking much action except to protect itself for the near future.
revised down due to plans to revoke rule by decree
...but it won't do any good...
Revising down due to plans to end rule by emergency decree.

Hungary's government appears to be preparing to scale back Orban's emergency powers (presumably with Orban's consent): "The Hungarian government plans to bring to an end controversial emergency legislation, which some critics described as creating the EU’s first dictatorship. Hungary’s justice minister, Judit Varga, announced on Tuesday that she would submit legislation to parliament imminently that would bring an end to the so-called 'state of danger' on 20 June. While in force, it has allowed the country’s prime minister, Viktor Orbán, to rule by decree, and had no fixed cut-off date." https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/26/hungarian-government-to-end-orbans-rule-by-decree-legislation-emergency-coronavirus
There are too many states who are quietly trending in Hungary's direction (Poland being most prominent).
Cutting my forecast in half as I don't see support for this at this time. This could change or I could be myopic, but right now, I doubt it.
I've personally WANTED Hungary to be "pushed back", and I've read nine ways to Sunday to "make" it into a likelihood I could support in the bet I'd like to to have made.

News that Hungary's rule by decree may end in June, thus, reducing the probability there will be a determination of a violation [1].

As others have commented, an extremely slow-moving process when Commission / Member States already have a lot else to do. Push for proceedings doesn't seem to be gaining much traction. Also, as this notes, for Article 7 to actually be effective there has to be a unanimous vote and Poland could veto https://www.euronews.com/2020/04/20/analysis-how-should-the-eu-deal-with-totally-incompatible-hungary
Cutting my forecast in half. The EU MEP's have a lot on their plate, and this one probably won't get any airtime.
It would take awhile just to get through votes. https://www.euractiv.com/section/justice-home-affairs/news/we-lack-alternatives-to-article-7-german-analyst/

The latest issue that has arisen with Germany could see these outstanding infringement issues put back on the agenda. However, so far there has been no movement from the Council on this and the next summit is likely to be dominated by Brexit. I'm going to revert to my base probability of around a 1/3rd chance as a result.

Crowd forecast at the time of writing is 15%. I don't see any reason to stray far from the crowd on this one, but want to veer slightly to higher side of the crowd on the principle that the EU is more likely to kick a guy like Orban when he's down. With the export sector getting crushed as a result of covid-19, he may find himself in the position of supplicant by year's end.
Rule 6. The more people/organizations involved in a decision the longer it will take.
Process likely to take a long time; the deciding factor seems to be not whether it will be done, but when will it be done.

Unlikely because EU will be pre-occupied with covid-19 for the foreseeable future. Members won't want to take action that risks more internal conflict. (Remember Brexit? Haven't heard much about that lately...) Also, requires supermajority votes of EU parliament Council, so fairly high bar.
As others have said; Covid-19 will dominate the EU for the short to medium term.
covid crisis too big for this to bother with. And Macron descrbies Orban as having hte most interesting ideas in Europe
covid19 is likely to dominate and overshadow a lot in 2020 while it does, Hungary can use it to justify their actions used articles linked in the descriptions and wikipedia as resources

Article 7.1: The mechanism begins with a proposal to find a "Clear Risk of Serious Breach" of EU values either by the Commission, the Parliament or one-third of member states. This is then approved by a two-thirds majority in Parliament. The accused country is then called to answer to the Council, which may then issue recommendations and vote by four-fifths to identify a breach. It tends to be a long process so even if it happens not likely to come to a quick resolution. https://www.theparliamentmagazine.eu/articles/news/pressure-mounts-eu-take-%E2%80%9Cswift%E2%80%9D-action-against-hungary

Hungary prepares to end legal recognition of trans people; Trans people fear more discrimination as Orbán pushes through law defining gender based on ‘sex at birth’. Two days ago. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/26/hungary-prepares-to-end-legal-recognition-of-trans-people

With Corona crises not being "over" by end 2020 this gives those forces in Europe support (i.e. an excuse) that do not want to trigger anything against Hungary (countries like Poland but also the conservative fraction)

Activating Article 7 has been previously debated for use against Austria, France and Romania, but official recommendations were never made. Currently, both Hungary and Poland are being discussed, but motions have not yet been put forth. (0/5; 0% base odds) Hungary and Poland can count on each other's veto votes. Hungary is also supported in the council by Spain and the Czech Republic, however, Hungary's conservative UK supporters have left the council, increasing odds somewhat. Still, it remains highly unlikely, as it would strain the already tense political relations, and the Corona-induced state of emergency is, for the time being, a sound justification.

They can make a determination they broke the rules without unanimity. They can sanction without unanimous vote but not suspend voting rights. Usually they send a group to investigate. That takes awhile. Under Coronavirus probably not sending anyone soon. Due to timing keeping this lower than 50%.

To correct a misconception: - An Article 7 motion "destroyer of rights, banisher of good faith, annihilator of voting rights" can just be vetoed by Poland, or by another country, and is unlikely to go through. - An Article 7.1. determination, which is the step beforehand, just requires a 4/5ths majority: "the Council, acting by a majority of four-fifths of its members after obtaining the consent of the European Parliament, may determine..." This might be the equivalent of "alright, we're getting serious here, guys".
EEc doesnlt like to rock the boat even when countries break their rules

"The Article 7 process, which suspends members' voting rights, is...unlikely to go anywhere. Another member state can simply veto it. Hungary has at least the backing of Poland and the Czech Republic." https://www.euronews.com/2020/04/20/analysis-how-should-the-eu-deal-with-totally-incompatible-hungary

I believe the EU has to start the process given the circumstances and that will happen this year. I just do not think a determination is feasible in 2020 based on previous time periods for the process. 6/5/2019 https://institutdelors.eu/en/publications/__trashed/ "It has now been more than a year since the Article 7 procedure of the Treaty on the European Union was initiated by the European Commission against Poland (on the 20th of December 2017) and more than six months since it was initiated by the Parliament against Hungary (on the 12th of September 2018)."
Hard for EU to focus on anything outside of COVID-19 and world economy issues at the moment and foreseeable future.
Covid-19 will dominate EU politics over the next 12 months.
A warning was issued to Poland in 2017, for arguably less than what Hungary are doing.
I think the EU has lost interest in this sort of thing and is more worried about coronavirus.
The EU is currently very weak and distracted by COVID19 and Britain leaving meaning they won’t want to have anymore disruption. It’s a shame.
The economical aspect of the coronavirus crisis will delay this issue.

The question asks about a determination by the Council of the EU, ('CEU'), under Art 7.1 of the TEU/TFEU, [1]. In my opinion it is important to understand the procedure under that article of the Treaty. It provides as follows:
The convid crisis will result in the EU having to show unity. Deviators are sanctioned.

The Council of Europe meets infrequently (once a month) and is now likely not meeting in person. Everyone is busy managing the COVID19 crisis, except Sweden, so the Council will not move on this issue until the earliest next year. It is important and significant to move on the issue but not immediately pressing..
The question says make a determination, not actually do anything, so that's quite possible.

Seems if it needs to be unanimous then Poland and other eastern european countries can prevent this being passed. Very low base rate (has this ever been used before? from my searches it seems not) make me shy towards the lower end on this question.
A few things to note:
They definitely need to do this. They won't.
Even the EPP starts to support this, finally.
Still a lot of months to go. A lot depends on the actions taken when the most severe consequences of Covid-19 are over.
If emergency measures are not removed if/when Coronavirus reduces the outcome seems reasonable.
Would be essential to preserve the EU integrity as a democratic body

Given their historic reluctance to act decisively in their own political arena, it seems unlikely that the EU will make any move before the pandemic wanes; on paper, Orban has not overstepped too significantly while Covid-19 is active. Of course his chances of giving up control at any point now are low, but it’s likely for the pandemic to remain a threat for most of 2020; even after it has come under control, more deliberations (and votes) will be required before the EU can proceed to 7.1.

The EU, much to their own horror, is very intent on attacking any member government for doing things for their own internal benefit instead of appearing to be a utopia. So I think there is a high likelihood they will do something this stupid and go through with it, against their own sanity. And I hope it causes the Hungarian government to say, "FOAD (or its Hungarian equivalent)" and decide they don't want to be a part of that corrupt organization.

Hattip @cdob63 for blatant breach of protocol, managing to smear the entire political class in one sentence. The MEP's don't need advice from the US, they have their own issues, budgets, bonds and holding the euro and the EU together as heilcopters drop euros on unsuspecting citizens. The problem is there aren't enough helicopters and the governments refuse to buy more for fear they will fly south. Sniping yes, voting unlikely, as it's the economy that really will need work to hold the EU together.
The EU has enough distractions between North and South, corona bonds, Brexit that I cannot forecast the need for them to disrupt the structure within EU borders.

The likelihood of achieving a unanimous decision on an Article 7.1 determination is low at current point in time. Poland will most likely support Hungary https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2020/04/europe-hungary-viktor-orban-coronavirus-covid19-democracy/609313/ other MS will be hesitant to rock the European boat during uncertain times for global economy

After some thought the EU has been trying to deal with Hungary and Poland for years. Poland and Hungary have each other's back. If their cases can be combined where they can not do that then maybe. Some baltic states or maybe right leaning EU states might not vote in favor either. Lowering.

This is the sort of issue that impels many of the Council to telephone US Senator McConnell for a recommendation about where to go for spine removal, then to sign up for US Senator Schumer's seminar, "Quacking and Flapping for the Terminally Ineffective."
The EU has damaged itself as late, The Eurosceptics are more likely to abandon the project.
